content.description:
CRIMES RECORDED IN COURT SESSIONS OF THE RELIGIOUS COURT IN CALVINIST NÎMES, FRANCE, 1561–1563 AND 1578–1583 CATEGORY OF OFFENSE 1561–1563 1578–1583 Total 1. Disputes and quarrels 256 (53%) 560 (50%) 816 (50%) 2. Behavioral offenses (dancing, swearing, frequenting taverns, etc.) 39 (8%) 256 (22%) 295 (18%) 3. Ecclesiastical matters (excluding marriage) 122 (26%) 161 (14%) 283 (18%) 4. Sexual misconduct 25 (5%) 96 (8%) 121 (7.5%) 5. Difficulties pertaining to marriage 22 (5%) 47 (4%) 69 (4%) Miscellaneous 16 (3%) 24 (2%) 40 (2.5%) TOTAL 480 (100%) 1,144 (100%) 1,624 (100%) 
Source: Adapted from Raymond A. Mentzer, “Disciplina nervus ecclesiae: The Calvinist Reform of Morals at Nîmes,” The Sixteenth Century Journal, Vol. 18, No. 1, Spring 1987.
content.question: Which of the following best describes the trend in the first two categories from the first period to the second period?

choices.label: The percentage of crimes categorized as disputes and quarrels increased, while the percentage of behavioral offenses remained relatively steady.
The percentage of crimes categorized as disputes and quarrels remained relatively steady, while the percentage of behavioral offenses decreased.
The percentage of crimes categorized as disputes and quarrels remained relatively steady, while the percentage of behavioral offenses increased.
The percentage of crimes categorized as disputes and quarrels decreased, while the percentage of behavioral offenses remained relatively steady.

content.answer: The percentage of crimes categorized as disputes and quarrels remained relatively steady, while the percentage of behavioral offenses increased.

skill.text: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.
